items.title: Fed's Waller vows to protect independence before Trump meeting

featured_image.name: Fed chair candidate Waller says he will 'absolutely' emphasize importance of the central bank's independence to Trump

items.description:
Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller vowed Wednesday to defend the central bank's independence as he prepared to meet with President Donald Trump about potentially succeeding Jerome Powell as Fed chair, a forceful declaration amid mounting concerns about political interference at the institution[1][2][3][4].

"Absolutely," Waller responded when asked whether he would defend the Fed's autonomy from presidential pressure, speaking at the Yale School of Management CEO Summit hours before his scheduled White House meeting[1][2]. The 20-year veteran of central banking research emphasized that while Trump "makes himself very clear on Truth Social" about his monetary policy preferences, direct interactions between a president and Fed chair should be limited to crisis situations[1][2].

items.title: Mexico offers to mediate US-Venezuela tensions

featured_image.name: Mexican President for talks between the US and Venezuela

items.description:
Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum offered her country as a mediator between the United States and Venezuela on Wednesday while sharply criticizing the United Nations for failing to prevent an escalating crisis that she warned could lead to bloodshed.

"We can always act as a negotiating point if the parties want," Sheinbaum said during her daily press conference[1][2][3][4]. "I call on the United Nations to fulfill its role. It has not been present. It must assume its role to prevent any bloodshed."[2][3][5][6]

Her appeal came one day after President Donald Trump announced a "total and complete blockade" of sanctioned oil tankers entering and leaving Venezuela, designating the government of Nicolás Maduro as a foreign terrorist organization[7][8][9][10]. Trump claimed Venezuela is "completely surrounded by the largest Armada ever assembled in the History of South America" and vowed the naval presence would expand until Venezuela returns "all of the oil, land, and other assets" he alleges were stolen from the United States[8][9][10].

items.title: Trump interviews Waller for Fed chair as independence questioned

featured_image.name: Fed chair candidate Waller says he will 'absolutely' emphasize importance of the central bank's independence to Trump

items.description:
President Donald Trump interviewed Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller on Wednesday as part of his search to replace Jerome Powell as chair of the central bank, with Waller pledging to emphasize the importance of Fed independence during their meeting[1][2][3].

Waller, speaking to CNBC earlier Wednesday, said he would "absolutely" stress the Fed's autonomy to Trump. "I have studied the independence of the Central Bank and its importance for 20 years," Waller said. "There is a vast record on this subject"[1][4].

The interview comes as Trump narrows his selection to replace Powell, whose term as Fed chair ends in May 2026[2][5]. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, who is leading the search, indicated an announcement is likely in early January 2026[6]. Waller is one of five finalists for the position, alongside National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett, former Fed Governor Kevin Warsh, Fed Vice Chair for Supervision Michelle Bowman, and BlackRock Chief Investment Officer Rick Rieder[2][7][8].

items.title: Nvidia and Alphabet vie for most valuable company status

featured_image.name: Should Nvidia Worry About AMD and Google Breathing Down Its ...

items.description:
Two tech titans are locked in a high-stakes race to become the world's most valuable company by the end of 2026, with Nvidia and Alphabet emerging as the leading contenders in an increasingly competitive artificial intelligence landscape.

As of December 17, 2025, Nvidia holds the top spot with a market capitalization of approximately $4.42 trillion, while Alphabet ranks third at around $3.7 trillion, trailing Apple's $4.05 trillion[1][2][3]. The $600 billion gap between the two AI powerhouses has sparked intense speculation about whether Google's parent company can close the distance in the coming year[4].

Prediction markets reflect the uncertainty. On Polymarket, both companies are assigned nearly identical probabilities—35% for Nvidia and 34% for Alphabet—of claiming the world's largest company title by December 2026[5][4]. A $100 bet on Alphabet overtaking Nvidia would pay out $265 if successful[4].

items.title: China backs Venezuela as Trump escalates military pressure

featured_image.name: Trump to meet with advisers on Venezuela as US ramps up pressure

items.description:
Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi expressed support for Venezuela amid mounting U.S. military operations on Wednesday, telling his Venezuelan counterpart that Beijing opposes "unilateral bullying" and backs nations defending their sovereignty[1][2][3].

The statement came during a phone call between Wang and Venezuelan Foreign Minister Yvan Gil as the Trump administration conducted classified briefings with Congress on its escalating Venezuela campaign[4][5][6]. Just hours earlier, Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth defended what Rubio called a "highly successful" counter-drug mission to House and Senate members[6][7].

items.title: FIFA raises 2026 World Cup winner prize to $50M

featured_image.name: FIFA announces 2026 World Cup winner to receive record $50M in prize money

items.description:
FIFA announced a record $50 million prize for the 2026 World Cup champion on Wednesday, marking a 50 percent increase in total prize money for the tournament[1][2][3]. The announcement came during a FIFA Council meeting in Doha, Qatar, as the organization faces mounting criticism over ticket prices that have sparked accusations of betraying dedicated fans[1][4][5].

The total prize pool will reach $727 million, with $655 million distributed among the 48 participating teams based on their performance[1][2][4]. This represents a significant jump from the 2022 World Cup in Qatar, where Argentina took home $42 million after defeating France in the final[1][2].

"The FIFA World Cup 2026 will also be groundbreaking in terms of its financial contribution to the global football community," FIFA President Gianni Infantino said in a statement[6][7]. Every team will receive at least $10.5 million, including a $1.5 million preparation allowance and a minimum $9 million prize for those eliminated in the group stage[4][8].

items.title: Turkey seeks to return Russian missiles, but US blocks F-35 access

featured_image.name: Turkey says no change in Russian S-400s amid U.S. talks on F-35s

items.description:
Turkey is attempting to end a controversial defense deal by returning Russian-made S-400 air defense systems to Moscow, a move that could reshape its relationship with NATO allies but faces continued resistance from Washington.

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan raised the issue with Russian President Vladimir Putin during a meeting in Turkmenistan on December 11, following earlier discussions between officials from both countries, according to people familiar with the matter[1]. The request marks a significant shift for Ankara, which has faced years of sanctions and diplomatic isolation over its 2017 purchase of the Russian missile system.

items.title: Trump to outline 2026 agenda amid falling approval

featured_image.name: Trump to tout accomplishments since taking office in primetime address

items.description:
President Donald Trump will address the nation Wednesday night at 9 p.m. ET from the White House, seeking to preview his 2026 agenda as his approval ratings decline to some of the lowest levels of his second term.

The primetime speech comes as Trump faces mounting economic concerns and growing Republican anxiety about the 2026 midterm elections. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said Trump will discuss his "historic accomplishments" over the past 11 months and outline plans to "continue delivering for the American people over the next three years"[1][2].

items.title: Stocks mixed as delayed jobs data clouds Fed rate outlook

featured_image.name: Unemployment Rates Ticks Upward In Latest Jobs Report

items.description:
U.S. stocks traded mixed Wednesday as Wall Street grappled with conflicting signals from a delayed November jobs report and awaited guidance from Federal Reserve officials on the path of interest rates heading into 2026.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 0.5% while the S&P 500 remained largely unchanged and the Nasdaq Composite slipped 0.3% as tech sector weakness resurfaced[1][2]. The session followed Tuesday's delayed jobs report, which showed employers added 64,000 positions in November—exceeding the 45,000 consensus estimate—but also revealed the unemployment rate jumped to 4.6%, the highest level since September 2021[3][4][5].

The murky labor market data, disrupted by a government shutdown that complicated collection efforts, left traders struggling to gauge the Federal Reserve's next moves. Fed Governor Chris Waller suggested Wednesday the central bank still has room to cut rates by "50 to 100 basis points," while New York Fed President John Williams was also scheduled to speak[2][6][7]. Markets have priced in just a 24% chance of a January rate cut, according to CME Group's FedWatch tool[8].

Oil prices provided a jolt to markets, surging more than 2% after President Donald Trump ordered a blockade of sanctioned oil tankers entering and leaving Venezuela[9][10][11]. West Texas Intermediate climbed above $56 per barrel while Brent crude hovered near $60, rebounding from their lowest levels since 2021[1][12][13].

items.title: Apple in talks to assemble iPhone chips in India

featured_image.name: Apple in talks with Indian chipmakers to assemble, package ...

items.description:
Apple is in early talks with Indian semiconductor companies to assemble and package iPhone chips, marking a potential expansion of its manufacturing footprint in the country as iPhone exports from India reached a record $2 billion in November[1][2][3][4][5][6].

The Cupertino-based tech giant has initiated preliminary discussions with CG Semi, part of the Murugappa Group, which is establishing an outsourced semiconductor assembly and test facility in Sanand, Gujarat[1][7][2][4]. This would mark the first time Apple has considered assembling and packaging certain chips in India, with display-related components seen as the most likely candidates[1][2][4].

"The companies are in the very initial stages of discussion," a person familiar with the matter told The Economic Times. "It is not clear what chips will be packaged out of the Sanand facility at this stage, but it will likely be display chips"[7][2][8].

items.title: General Mills results reflect consumer pullback and economic slowdown

featured_image.name: US retail sales unexpectedly unchanged in October

items.description:
General Mills reported earnings that beat Wall Street expectations Wednesday, but the food giant's results underscored a broader economic reality taking shape: American consumers are pulling back, and the economy is losing momentum as 2025 draws to a close.

The maker of Cheerios and Nature Valley granola bars posted adjusted earnings per share of $1.10, topping analyst estimates of $1.03[1][2][3]. Yet beneath the headline beat, the Minneapolis-based company revealed a challenging landscape. Revenue fell 7% to $4.86 billion, with organic net sales down 1%[1][2]. Most troubling, adjusted operating profit plunged 20% as margins compressed 150 basis points[1][1].

"Lower-income and more middle-class shoppers are increasingly reaching for generic store brands and looking to cut their grocery bills any way they can," according to an analysis in Qz[4]. The pressure was acute in General Mills' North America business, where operating profit dropped more than 20% year-over-year[4].

The company's struggles arrived alongside a wave of disappointing economic data released this week. The unemployment rate climbed to 4.6% in November, the highest level in four years[5][6][7]. U.S. business activity growth slowed to a six-month low in December, with the S&P Global Flash Composite PMI falling to 53.0 from 54.2 in November[8][9][10]. Retail sales were unchanged in October, defying expectations for holiday shopping momentum[11][12].

items.title: China builds prototype for advanced chip production

featured_image.name: China's racing to beat U.S. chip curbs. How its supply chain stacks up

items.description:
Chinese scientists in Shenzhen have completed a prototype machine capable of producing cutting-edge semiconductor chips, marking a significant advance in Beijing's drive for technological self-sufficiency and defying Western predictions that such progress would take a decade or more, according to a Reuters investigation published Tuesday.

The machine, completed in early 2025 and currently undergoing tests, was built by former engineers from Dutch semiconductor giant ASML who reverse-engineered the company's extreme ultraviolet lithography systems[1][2][3]. While the prototype successfully generates EUV light—the key technology for manufacturing advanced chips that power artificial intelligence systems and smartphones—it has not yet produced working chips, according to two people with knowledge of the project[1][2][3].

The development comes as China pursues what sources described as its own "Manhattan Project" for semiconductors, a six-year government initiative to achieve complete independence from Western chip technology[1][2][3]. President Xi Jinping has made semiconductor self-sufficiency a top national priority, with the effort coordinated by his confidant Ding Xuexiang, who heads the Communist Party's Central Science and Technology Commission[1][2][3]. Chinese electronics giant Huawei plays a central role in coordinating thousands of engineers across state research institutions and companies nationwide[1][2][3].

items.title: Gene editing sorts mosquitoes by color for disease control

featured_image.name: Gene-edited mosquitoes slash malaria spread 93% using self ...

items.description:
Scientists have developed a gene-editing breakthrough that makes separating male and female mosquitoes as simple as distinguishing dark from pale insects, a development that could transform efforts to control diseases like dengue, Zika and chikungunya[1][2][3].

The research, published in Nature Communications on December 10, introduces a genetically engineered strain of the Asian tiger mosquito where all males appear dark and all females remain pale yellow[2][1][4]. Led by Doron Zaada and Prof. Philippos Papathanos from Hebrew University's Department of Entomology, the method addresses a critical bottleneck in mosquito control programs that rely on releasing only sterile males into wild populations[1][2][3].

items.title: Fossil discoveries reveal complex human evolution beyond linear model

featured_image.name: Researchers make extraordinary discovery that could completely ...

items.description: Scientists have unveiled a 1.5-million-year-old human ancestor fossil with an unexpectedly primitive face, marking the latest in a series of discoveries reshaping our understanding of early human evolution and migration from Africa. The finding, published Monday in Nature Communications, challenges long-held assumptions about how and where our species emerged[1][2][3].

items.title: California gives Tesla 60 days to fix Autopilot claims

featured_image.name: CA DMV claims Tesla misled drivers on Autopilot capabilities - ABC11

items.description:
California regulators have postponed a 30-day sales suspension for Tesla, giving the electric vehicle maker 60 days to address what a judge ruled were misleading marketing claims about its Autopilot driver-assistance technology.

The California Department of Motor Vehicles on Tuesday adopted an administrative law judge's finding that Tesla violated state law by using the terms "Autopilot" and "Full Self-Driving Capability" to describe features that do not make its vehicles autonomous[1][2]. However, the agency opted to delay enforcement and spare the company's manufacturing operations, providing what DMV Director Steve Gordon called "one more chance" to remedy the situation[3][4].

items.title: Ford cancels $6.5B battery deal in EV retreat

featured_image.name: Ford To Stop Making All Electric F-150 Truck, In Shift To Hybrids

items.description:
Ford Motor on Wednesday announced the cancellation of a $6.5 billion electric vehicle battery supply contract with South Korea's LG Energy Solution, the latest fallout from the automaker's massive retreat from its EV ambitions. The termination comes as Ford disclosed earlier this week it will take a $19.5 billion writedown while abandoning several all-electric models in response to weakening demand and the Trump administration's elimination of EV tax incentives[1][2][3][4].

LG Energy Solution said in a regulatory filing Wednesday that Ford notified the company of its decision to halt production of certain EV models due to "policy changes and shifts in outlook for EV demand"[1][3][4]. The canceled contract, signed in October 2024, was for 75 gigawatt-hours of batteries to be supplied from 2027 to 2032 for Ford's commercial vehicles[3][5][6]. A separate smaller contract for 34 gigawatt-hours from 2026 to 2030 remains in place[6].

items.title: FIFA boosts World Cup prize money, adds $60 tickets after backlash

featured_image.name: FIFA slashes some 2026 World Cup ticket prices after backlash

items.description:
FIFA announced a record-breaking 50% increase in prize money for the 2026 World Cup on Wednesday, with the winning team set to receive $50 million, while simultaneously introducing a limited number of $60 tickets following intense backlash over prohibitive pricing.

The dual announcements came from a FIFA Council meeting in Doha, Qatar, with the prize money increase representing a significant financial boost for participating nations and the ticket price reduction marking a rare climbdown for the governing body after widespread criticism from fan groups across Europe and beyond[1][2][3][4].

items.title: UK AI tool speeds nuclear fusion modeling 1,000x

featured_image.name: Nuclear fusion is one step closer with new AI breakthrough ...

items.description:
Scientists have unveiled a tool that can simulate complex fusion plasma turbulence in seconds rather than days, marking a potential turning point in the race to develop commercial fusion energy.

A team from the UK Atomic Energy Authority, Johannes Kepler University in Austria, and Emmi AI announced on December 16 that their artificial intelligence model, GyroSwin, can perform five-dimensional plasma simulations up to 1,000 times faster than conventional supercomputer methods[1][2]. The breakthrough addresses one of fusion energy's most stubborn challenges: accurately modeling the turbulent behavior of superheated plasma without consuming months of computing time and resources.

items.title: Colossal Foundation doubles funding to $100M for conservation tech

featured_image.name: How Colossal Biosciences Is Decoding the Secret Language of Wolves

items.description:
The Colossal Foundation, the nonprofit arm of Dallas-based Colossal Biosciences, announced Tuesday it has secured an additional $50 million in funding, doubling its total to $100 million just one year after its launch[1][2][3][4][5]. The new capital will expand the foundation's deployment of biotechnology and artificial intelligence to combat species extinction, including cloning endangered wolves and developing vaccines for elephants.

In its inaugural year, the foundation launched dozens of projects supporting more than 40 species across six continents, partnering with over 55 conservation, Indigenous and academic organizations[5][6]. The expansion comes as global wildlife populations have declined by 73% over the past 50 years and conservation efforts face a $700 billion annual funding gap[7][8][9][10][11].

items.title: Stock futures climb as weak jobs data fuels Fed rate cut bets

featured_image.name: Markets News, Dec. 16, 2025: S&P 500, Dow Fall After Jobs Data Shows Surprising Rise in Unemployment; Nasdaq Ticks Higher to Snap Losing Streak

items.description:
U.S. stock futures climbed Wednesday morning as investors digested mixed employment data and recalibrated expectations for Federal Reserve interest rate cuts in early 2026, halting a three-day losing streak for major indexes.

S&P 500 futures rose 0.36% while Nasdaq futures gained 0.45%, according to multiple market reports[1][2][3]. The rally came despite Tuesday's jobs report showing unemployment hit 4.6%, its highest level since September 2021[4][5][6]. The upbeat sentiment reflected growing trader conviction that the softening labor market would push the Fed to resume rate cuts despite recent hawkish signals from policymakers.
